newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish zloty stable, depos slip lower.
newsitem.headline: Polish zloty stable, depos slip lower.

text.p: The Polish zloty held virtually flat against the basket of currencies on Wednesday with foreign investors remaining on the sidelines during the light session.

The zloty mirrored dollar/mark trends on world markets and remained around resistance at 1.5 percent above parity all day -- the level where the zloty was expected to stay for the next several days, dealers said.
"The zloty tracked dollar/mark with little other movements on the market. It seems likely to remain at 1.5 percent for the next few days," said Tomasz Nowakowski, forex dealer at Bank Handlowy SA.
The zloty closed at 1.52/1.49 percent from the trading band centre, a touch down from Tuesday's close at 1.56/1.50 percent.
It closed at 3.2230/40 to the dollar, down from 3.2175/95 on Tuesday and at 1.8779/84 to the mark, up from 1.8795/05.
The central bank chief Hanna Gronkiewicz-Waltz said the bank was satisfied with the current level of the zloty and saw no inflationary pressure resulting from its recent weakening.
The zloty lost more than two percent late in May amid a foreign investor withdrawal from the region triggered by the Czech crown's slump before rebounding one percent to 1.5 percent from parity.

The average yield of the 39-week T-bill increased 0.05 point to 21.48 percent at Wednesday's tender, while the 26-week yield rose 0.07 to 21.44 percent. The finance ministry sold 336 million zlotys of the bills at the 600 million zloty auction.

Overnight and tomorrow/next rates both fell about 30 basis points to close at 21.95/22.15 and 22.05/22.25 percent respectively as banks continued to have surpluses in monthly average reserve positions.
